query: Build a simple WORDPRESS like CMS with admin dashboard
key_findings: Leverage the WordPress REST API for building custom front-end applications; it allows you to interact with your CMS data using standard HTTP requests.
Utilize WordPress's built-in user roles and capabilities to manage permissions effectively in your admin dashboard, ensuring secure access control.
Implement custom post types and taxonomies to extend the functionality of your CMS, allowing for more tailored content management beyond standard posts and pages.
Follow best practices for plugin development by adhering to the WordPress Coding Standards, which enhances code quality and maintainability.
Use the WordPress enqueue script method to properly load CSS and JavaScript files, preventing conflicts and ensuring optimal performance.
Avoid direct database queries; instead, use the WordPress database abstraction layer (wpdb) to ensure compatibility and security against SQL injection.
Implement nonce verification for form submissions in the admin dashboard to protect against CSRF attacks, enhancing security.
Consider using a theme framework or starter theme to streamline the development process and maintain consistency across your CMS's UI.
Regularly update WordPress core, themes, and plugins to mitigate security vulnerabilities and ensure compatibility with the latest features.
Utilize JSON or XML data formats for API responses to facilitate easy integration with third-party services and applications.

code_examples.description: Creating a custom post type in WordPress
code_examples.code:
<?php
function create_post_type() {
    register_post_type('custom_type', [
        'labels' => [
            'name' => __('Custom Types'),
            'singular_name' => __('Custom Type')
        ],
        'public' => true,
        'has_archive' => true,
        'supports' => ['title', 'editor', 'thumbnail'],
    ]);
}
add_action('init', 'create_post_type');

code_examples.description: Basic REST API endpoint in WordPress
code_examples.code:
<?php
function custom_api_endpoint() {
    register_rest_route('custom/v1', '/data/', [
        'methods' => 'GET',
        'callback' => 'get_custom_data',
    ]);
}
add_action('rest_api_init', 'custom_api_endpoint');

function get_custom_data() {
    return new WP_REST_Response(['data' => 'Hello World'], 200);
}

best_practices: Use child themes for customizations to avoid losing changes during updates.
Regularly update WordPress core, themes, and plugins to ensure security and performance.
Implement caching mechanisms (e.g., using plugins like W3 Total Cache) to improve site performance.
Utilize the built-in user roles and capabilities to manage access effectively.
Backup your WordPress site regularly using plugins or server-level solutions.
common_pitfalls: Neglecting to sanitize and validate user input can lead to security vulnerabilities.
Overloading the site with too many plugins can slow down performance and create conflicts.
Failing to optimize images can lead to longer load times and affect user experience.
Not using a staging environment for testing changes can result in downtime or errors on the live site.
implementation_patterns: Use a modular approach by creating custom plugins for specific functionalities to keep the core site clean.
Implement a theme framework to allow for easy customization and scalability.
Utilize hooks and filters to modify default WordPress behavior without altering core files.

integration_requirements.authentication: OAuth 2.0 for REST API access, basic authentication for plugin development.

performance_considerations: Use a Content Delivery Network (CDN) to serve static files quickly to users around the globe.
Optimize database queries and regularly clean up the database to maintain performance.
Minimize HTTP requests by combining CSS and JavaScript files where possible.
security_considerations: Implement SSL to encrypt data transmitted between the server and users.
Use security plugins (e.g., Wordfence) to monitor and protect against threats.
Regularly review user roles and permissions to ensure least privilege access.
